newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian stocks dive, market to remain sleepy.
newsitem.headline: Croatian stocks dive, market to remain sleepy.

text.p: Croatian stocks took a dive in lacklustre trade on Friday as big buyers stayed away from the market and traders said the lull would extend well into next week.
"The market is listless and asleep. It seems to be lacking inspiration," one trader at the Metroholding brokerage said.
"Foreign buyers may be absent... This is a sensitive market and two stronger investors can easily influence the price trend," she said.
Analysts foresaw scarce market activity for next week, due to a national holiday on May 1.

"Many traders are bound to close shop earlier. I just can't see any active trading on Tuesday and Wednesday," an analyst at the big brokerage said, adding he expected a general market recovery sometime before summer.
Eleven of 18 active isssues fell, three rose and four were flat. Turnover was halved at 1.5 million kuna, volume fell to 3,640 shares from 6,852.
Drugs firm Pliva edged down four kuna to 476, with 688 units sold. Zagrebacka Banka lost 15 kuna to 2,200 on a meagre volume of 13 shares.
Analysts said there was still room for growth of the two fully-listed stocks, especially for Zagrebacka which plans to issue bonds in May.
Only Varazdinska Banka of the three fully-listed issues bucked the downward trend, climbing 1,000 kuna to 44,000 but selling only four shares.
Top gainer was Zagreb's Intercontinental hotel, up five kuna or 3.03 percent to 270 kuna, with 100 units sold.
Leading decliner cable maker Elka lost 19 kuna or 12.67 percent to 131 kuna, with 155 shares changing hands.
Confectioner Kras tumbled 25 kuna to 415 on volume of 288 units.
"News that Kras is definitely listed for voucher privatisation negatively affected its price. This diminished hopes its shares would be floated abroad," the analyst said.
Most active food processor Podravka inched down 0.50 kuna to 305 on volume of 1,462 shares.
"Podravka won't see real trading before it releases annual results in May...The rumour is that they are not great, so its price has not been rising," the analyst said.
